oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Court House and Confederate Monument on Public Square in Franklin

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Monuments; Water towers; Trees
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Franklin Courthouse, showing a trolley sitting outside and a water tower to the right. The Confederate Monument, featuring a soldier standing on a tall stone pedestal, can be seen on the right side of the image.

The monument was erected November 30, 1899, by Franklin Chapter 14 of the United Daughters of the Confederacy. Although the Franklin battlefield was small, casualties (particularly Confederate casualties) were high.; Federal casualties amounted to 2,500 men; Confederate casualties were nearly three times that number (7,000 soldiers). Fifteen of 28 Confederate generals were lost in the battle.
